title: New Orleans
content:
The news just announced that the National Guard is being sent into New Orleans to evacuate it for the next two months. So all the displaced residents will need the help of organizations like the Red Cross. Would it be a good idea for the Typographic community to make a relief glyph font to be sold to raise money for an organization like the Red Cross? Fortunately all the New York radio stations are doing public service announcements appealling for donations of time or money to the Red Cross. Any Thoughts?

I would be curious to ask Jim or Tamye how much of an impact they’ve made with the previous [FontAid](http://web.archive.org/web/20080312104649/http:/www.typesociety.org/fontaid.html) programs.

While Font Aid and Building Letters cannot make a giant impact in comparison to overall disaster relief efforts, that should never stop us from doing what we can. As of tonight, the Font Aid III effort has raised over $17,600 to benefit the victims of the Southeast Asian tsunami and floods. This figure is from sales of the collaborative “Fleurons of Hope” font and the donated proceeds from sales of specific fonts from a group of MyFonts foundries earlier in the year.

“Building Letters,” Jim Richardson’s side of the project, is not yet available, and I don’t have a release date at this moment. But when BL does go on sale, it will certainly raise more money for the cause.

The Font Aid II September 11 font raised more than $5,000 in 2001-2002. I am not privy to the results of the inaugural Font Aid sales, as the project was under designer Claes Källarsson’s direction at that time (he originated the first Font Aid to assist war and disaster refugees).

If you haven’t done so already, license your copy of Fleurons of Hope, please! Not only does every cent of the selling price go to a good cause, it’s a beautiful font and a heartfelt gift from the international type and design community who worked together to create it.

I’ve been pondering the response to the disaster in Louisiana.

I think there is an understandable amazement among many people, both within the USA and abroad, that the _the world’s only superpower_ seems so woefully unprepared for this disaster at both the local and national levels. David is quite right to point out that now the relief and rescue effort is actually under way some remarkable things are being achieved — things that many other countries would not be be able to achieve —, but it is reasonable to ask why it took so long. And there is a perfectly reasonable expectation that the _richest nation on the planet_ should be able to handle this situation much better than it has: there is no shortage of material resources, so inevitably it looks like a massive political failure.

When millions of people around the world made donations to help the victims of the South Asian tsunami, it was with the knowledge that most of the countries affected were desperately poor by comparison to the western industrialised nations, and that there were neither the material resources nor infrastructure to provide adequate relief without massive international assistance. Quite simply, no one expected the governments of those countries to be able to cope, especially since the effect of the tsunami was so wide spread and the death toll so high. While the tragedy of what is happening in New Orleans and surrounding areas is terrible — I’ve made a donation to the American Red Cross, which seems the most direct means to support the immediate relief effort\* —, it is localised and taking place against a backdrop of a country with a per capita GDP more than ten times larger than that of most of the nations affected by the tsunami. The USA should be able to help itself. Rather than wondering whether or not Americans expect too much or too little from their government, anyone might reasonably ask what the heck any government is supposed to be for if not to help its own citizens at such times?

I’m glad to be able to make personal donations to organisations like the Red Cross, but such private charitable assistance doesn’t let governments off the hook for caring for their citizens.

Part of the larger problem as John Hudson and others have pointed out are years of issues that have continued to pile up over the years.

The issue that this comment speaks to is the fact that 30-40% of the population of New Orleans was already poverty striken. For the wealthiest industrialized nation in the world (and one of the largest cities in the United States) that statistic is INEXCUSABLE.

We live in a country where many cities are divided by poverty and race. This particularly gets my goat because my hometown of Cincinnati, Ohio (a very segregated city) socio-economic standing is almost literally Black and White.

The survival of the fittest attitudes I’ve seen expressed I often find naive and dismissive. You’ll find very few people who have actually gone hungry share this viewpoint. My point is this: no one wants to be poor, and when there is such a disproportionate number of people who are in an allegedly wealthy nation, its time to access what the problem is.

First and foremost we are human beings, the government and politicians need to start reflecting that. This isn’t just the problem of the citizens of the Gulf, its everyone’s problem. If you think this isn’t your problem, then you’re part of it.

_...what does that say about Democracy?_

That it is corruptible — but then so are other systems of government —, and that it reflects the social, economic and cultural mores of the society (as it did in classical Athens, republican Rome, and has on the Isle of Man for some 1,200 years). In other words, having a democracy does not automatically produce a majority population of well informed and civil minded democrats. If many of the cultural forces in your country are running counter to that end, you can’t expect your democracy to function very well. The necessary relationship between effective democracy and the institutions of society that are needed to inculcate democratic social values should be obvious. Indeed, they are obvious, which is why they are deliberately targeted by forces that wish to undermine or exert control over the democratic process. The problems of democracy in the USA are the problems of a system that is not strong enough to counter the interests of capital, and unfortunately the US constitution seems to have been designed to put institutional brakes on democratic development, so US democracy is ill equiped to respond to the much more dynamic forces of wealth and power that have developed in that country.

When I was in college, my German professor spoke of a German colleague who said she was amazed the first time she saw a homeless person sleeping on the street of an American city. In Germany, this would not happen. The authorities would take that person somewhere where they would be taken care of. (So she said at the time. It sounds accurate, cos I’ve never seen a homeless person in Germany.)

In the US, local government officials generally cannot arrest someone without suspicion of a crime being committed. A person cannot be institutionalized without being a danger to himself or others.
